001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003/**
004 * A group of similar methods for getting hashes of points based on long coordinates in 2, 3, 4, or 6 dimensions and
005 * a long for state; like {@link PointHash} but faster and maybe not as high-quality. This implementation has
006 * high enough quality to be useful as a source of random numbers based on positions, but would likely not be a good
007 * option in a hash table (or at least not as good as the tailored implementation of {@link Coord#hashCode()}, for
008 * instance). At low dimensions, this is a little faster than {@link PointHash}, but this class doesn't slow 
009 * down much at all as more dimensions are used, while PointHash and most other implementations do slow down. You
010 * can also consider {@link IntPointHash} if your input and output types are usually int, since it's even faster.
011 * <br>
012 * This implements {@link IPointHash} and has a long it uses internally for state, exposed by {@link #getState()}.
013 */
014public final class HastyPointHash extends IPointHash.LongImpl {
015
016    public static final HastyPointHash INSTANCE = new HastyPointHash();
017
018    @Override
019    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int state) {
020        return (int)hashAll(x, y, state);
021    }
022
023    @Override
024    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int state) {
025        return (int)hashAll(x, y, z, state);
026    }
027
028    @Override
029    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int state) {
030        return (int)hashAll(x, y, z, w, state);
031    }
032
033    @Override
034    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int state) {
035        return (int)hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, state);
036    }
037    
038    @Override
039    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int state) {
040        return (int)hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, v, state);
041    }
042    
043    public long getState(){
044        return state;
045    }
046
047    /**
048     * Gets a 64-bit point hash of a 2D point (x and y are both longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
049     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
050     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
051     * <br>
052     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
053     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
054     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
055     * generalized ratio. See
056     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
057     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
058     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
059     * @param x x position; any long
060     * @param y y position; any long
061     * @param s the state/seed; any long
062     * @return 64-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state
063     */
064    public static long hashAll(long x, long y, long s) {
065        y += s * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L;
066        x += y * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L;
067        s += x * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L;
068        return ((s = (s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) ^ s >>> 25);
069    }
070
071    /**
072     * Gets a 64-bit point hash of a 3D point (x, y, and z are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
073     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
074     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
075     * <br>
076     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
077     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
078     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
079     * generalized ratio. See
080     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
081     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
082     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
083     * @param x x position; any long
084     * @param y y position; any long
085     * @param z z position; any long
086     * @param s the state/seed; any long
087     * @return 64-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state
088     */
089    public static long hashAll(long x, long y, long z, long s) {
090        z += s * 0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L;
091        y += z * 0xBBE0563303A4615FL;
092        x += y * 0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L;
093        s += x * 0x89E182857D9ED689L;
094        return ((s = (s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) ^ s >>> 25);
095    }
096
097    /**
098     * Gets a 64-bit point hash of a 4D point (x, y, z, and w are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
099     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
100     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
101     * <br>
102     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
103     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
104     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
105     * generalized ratio. See
106     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
107     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
108     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
109     * @param x x position; any long
110     * @param y y position; any long
111     * @param z z position; any long
112     * @param w w position; any long
113     * @param s the state; any long
114     * @return 64-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state
115     */
116    public static long hashAll(long x, long y, long z, long w, long s) {
117        w += s * 0xE19B01AA9D42C633L;
118        z += w * 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L;
119        y += z * 0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL;
120        x += y * 0x9A69443F36F710E7L;
121        s += x * 0x881403B9339BD42DL;
122        return ((s = (s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) ^ s >>> 25);
123    }
124
125    /**
126     * Gets a 64-bit point hash of a 5D point (x, y, z, w, and u are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This
127     * point hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
128     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
129     * <br>
130     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
131     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
132     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
133     * generalized ratio. See
134     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
135     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
136     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
137     * @param x x position; any long
138     * @param y y position; any long
139     * @param z z position; any long
140     * @param w w position; any long
141     * @param u u position; any long
142     * @param s the state; any long
143     * @return 64-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u point with the given state
144     */
145    public static long hashAll(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long s) {
146        u += s * 0xE60E2B722B53AEEBL;
147        w += u * 0xCEBD76D9EDB6A8EFL;
148        z += w * 0xB9C9AA3A51D00B65L;
149        y += z * 0xA6F5777F6F88983FL;
150        x += y * 0x9609C71EB7D03F7BL;
151        s += x * 0x86D516E50B04AB1BL;
152        return ((s = (s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) ^ s >>> 25);
153    }
154
155    /**
156     * Gets a 64-bit point hash of a 6D point (x, y, z, w, u, and v are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This
157     * point hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
158     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
159     * <br>
160     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
161     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
162     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
163     * generalized ratio. See
164     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
165     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
166     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
167     * @param x x position; any long
168     * @param y y position; any long
169     * @param z z position; any long
170     * @param w w position; any long
171     * @param u u position; any long
172     * @param v v position; any long
173     * @param s the state; any long
174     * @return 64-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state
175     */
176    public static long hashAll(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long v, long s) {
177        v += s * 0xE95E1DD17D35800DL;
178        u += v * 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL;
179        w += u * 0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L;
180        z += w * 0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL;
181        y += z * 0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L;
182        x += y * 0x92E852C80D153DB3L;
183        s += x * 0x85EB75C3024385C3L;
184        return ((s = (s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) ^ s >>> 25);
185    }
186    /**
187     * Gets an 8-bit point hash of a 2D point (x and y are both longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
188     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
189     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
190     * <br>
191     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
192     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
193     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
194     * generalized ratio. See
195     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
196     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
197     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
198     * @param x x position; any long
199     * @param y y position; any long
200     * @param s the state/seed; any long
201     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state
202     */
203    public static int hash256(long x, long y, long s) {
204        y += s * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L;
205        x += y * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L;
206        s += x * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L;
207        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 56);
208    }
209
210    /**
211     * Gets an 8-bit point hash of a 3D point (x, y, and z are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
212     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
213     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
214     * <br>
215     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
216     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
217     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
218     * generalized ratio. See
219     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
220     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
221     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
222     * @param x x position; any long
223     * @param y y position; any long
224     * @param z z position; any long
225     * @param s the state/seed; any long
226     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state
227     */
228    public static int hash256(long x, long y, long z, long s) {
229        z += s * 0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L;
230        y += z * 0xBBE0563303A4615FL;
231        x += y * 0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L;
232        s += x * 0x89E182857D9ED689L;
233        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 56);
234    }

236    /**
237     * Gets an 8-bit point hash of a 4D point (x, y, z, and w are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
238     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
239     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
240     * <br>
241     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
242     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
243     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
244     * generalized ratio. See
245     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
246     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
247     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
248     * @param x x position; any long
249     * @param y y position; any long
250     * @param z z position; any long
251     * @param w w position; any long
252     * @param s the state; any long
253     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state
254     */
255    public static int hash256(long x, long y, long z, long w, long s) {
256        w += s * 0xE19B01AA9D42C633L;
257        z += w * 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L;

259        x += y * 0x9A69443F36F710E7L;

261        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 56);
262    }

265    /**
266     * Gets an 8-bit point hash of a 5D point (x, y, z, w, and u are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
267     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
268     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
269     * <br>
270     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
271     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
272     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
273     * generalized ratio. See
274     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
275     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
276     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
277     * @param x x position; any long
278     * @param y y position; any long
279     * @param z z position; any long
280     * @param w w position; any long
281     * @param u u position; any long
282     * @param s the state; any long
283     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u point with the given state
284     */
285    public static int hash256(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long s) {
286        u += s * 0xE60E2B722B53AEEBL;
287        w += u * 0xCEBD76D9EDB6A8EFL;
288        z += w * 0xB9C9AA3A51D00B65L;
289        y += z * 0xA6F5777F6F88983FL;
290        x += y * 0x9609C71EB7D03F7BL;
291        s += x * 0x86D516E50B04AB1BL;
292        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 56);
293    }

295    /**
296     * Gets an 8-bit point hash of a 6D point (x, y, z, w, u, and v are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This
297     * point hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
298     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
299     * <br>
300     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
301     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
302     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
303     * generalized ratio. See
304     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
305     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
306     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
307     * @param x x position; any long
308     * @param y y position; any long
309     * @param z z position; any long
310     * @param w w position; any long
311     * @param u u position; any long
312     * @param v v position; any long
313     * @param s the state; any long
314     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state
315     */
316    public static int hash256(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long v, long s) {
317        v += s * 0xE95E1DD17D35800DL;
318        u += v * 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL;
319        w += u * 0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L;
320        z += w * 0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL;
321        y += z * 0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L;
322        x += y * 0x92E852C80D153DB3L;
323        s += x * 0x85EB75C3024385C3L;
324        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 56);
325    }
326    /**
327     * Gets a 5-bit point hash of a 2D point (x and y are both longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
328     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
329     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
330     * <br>
331     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
332     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
333     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
334     * generalized ratio. See
335     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
336     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
337     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
338     * @param x x position; any long
339     * @param y y position; any long
340     * @param s the state/seed; any long
341     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state
342     */
343    public static int hash32(long x, long y, long s) {
344        y += s * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L;
345        x += y * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L;
346        s += x * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L;
347        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 59);
348    }

350    /**
351     * Gets a 5-bit point hash of a 3D point (x, y, and z are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
352     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
353     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
354     * <br>
355     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
356     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
357     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
358     * generalized ratio. See
359     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
360     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
361     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
362     * @param x x position; any long
363     * @param y y position; any long
364     * @param z z position; any long
365     * @param s the state/seed; any long
366     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state
367     */
368    public static int hash32(long x, long y, long z, long s) {
369        z += s * 0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L;
370        y += z * 0xBBE0563303A4615FL;
371        x += y * 0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L;
372        s += x * 0x89E182857D9ED689L;
373        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 59);
374    }

376    /**
377     * Gets a 5-bit point hash of a 4D point (x, y, z, and w are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
378     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
379     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
380     * <br>
381     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
382     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
383     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
384     * generalized ratio. See
385     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
386     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
387     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
388     * @param x x position; any long
389     * @param y y position; any long
390     * @param z z position; any long
391     * @param w w position; any long
392     * @param s the state; any long
393     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state
394     */
395    public static int hash32(long x, long y, long z, long w, long s) {
396        w += s * 0xE19B01AA9D42C633L;
397        z += w * 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L;
398        y += z * 0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL;
399        x += y * 0x9A69443F36F710E7L;
400        s += x * 0x881403B9339BD42DL;
401        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 59);
402    }

404    /**
405     * Gets a 5-bit point hash of a 6D point (x, y, z, w, u, and v are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This
406     * point hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
407     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
408     * <br>
409     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
410     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
411     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
412     * generalized ratio. See
413     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
414     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
415     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
416     * @param x x position; any long
417     * @param y y position; any long
418     * @param z z position; any long
419     * @param w w position; any long
420     * @param u u position; any long
421     * @param v v position; any long
422     * @param s the state; any long
423     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state
424     */
425    public static int hash32(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long v, long s) {
426        v += s * 0xE95E1DD17D35800DL;
427        u += v * 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL;
428        w += u * 0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L;
429        z += w * 0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL;
430        y += z * 0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L;
431        x += y * 0x92E852C80D153DB3L;
432        s += x * 0x85EB75C3024385C3L;
433        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 59);
434    }
435    
436    /**
437     * Gets a 6-bit point hash of a 2D point (x and y are both longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
438     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
439     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
440     * <br>
441     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
442     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
443     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
444     * generalized ratio. See
445     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
446     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
447     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
448     * @param x x position; any long
449     * @param y y position; any long
450     * @param s the state/seed; any long
451     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state
452     */
453    public static int hash64(long x, long y, long s) {
454        y += s * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L;
455        x += y * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L;
456        s += x * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L;
457        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 58);
458    }
459
460    /**
461     * Gets a 6-bit point hash of a 3D point (x, y, and z are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
462     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
463     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
464     * <br>
465     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
466     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
467     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
468     * generalized ratio. See
469     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
470     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
471     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
472     * @param x x position; any long
473     * @param y y position; any long
474     * @param z z position; any long
475     * @param s the state/seed; any long
476     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state
477     */
478    public static int hash64(long x, long y, long z, long s) {
479        z += s * 0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L;
480        y += z * 0xBBE0563303A4615FL;
481        x += y * 0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L;
482        s += x * 0x89E182857D9ED689L;
483        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 58);
484    }
485
486    /**
487     * Gets a 6-bit point hash of a 4D point (x, y, z, and w are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
488     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
489     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
490     * <br>
491     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
492     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
493     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
494     * generalized ratio. See
495     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
496     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
497     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
498     * @param x x position; any long
499     * @param y y position; any long
500     * @param z z position; any long
501     * @param w w position; any long
502     * @param s the state; any long
503     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state
504     */
505    public static int hash64(long x, long y, long z, long w, long s) {
506        w += s * 0xE19B01AA9D42C633L;
507        z += w * 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L;
508        y += z * 0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL;
509        x += y * 0x9A69443F36F710E7L;
510        s += x * 0x881403B9339BD42DL;
511        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 58);
512    }
513
514    /**
515     * Gets a 6-bit point hash of a 6D point (x, y, z, w, u, and v are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This
516     * point hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
517     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
518     * <br>
519     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
520     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
521     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
522     * generalized ratio. See
523     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
524     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
525     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
526     * @param x x position; any long
527     * @param y y position; any long
528     * @param z z position; any long
529     * @param w w position; any long
530     * @param u u position; any long
531     * @param v v position; any long
532     * @param s the state; any long
533     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state
534     */
535    public static int hash64(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long v, long s) {
536        v += s * 0xE95E1DD17D35800DL;
537        u += v * 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL;
538        w += u * 0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L;
539        z += w * 0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL;
540        y += z * 0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L;
541        x += y * 0x92E852C80D153DB3L;
542        s += x * 0x85EB75C3024385C3L;
543        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 58);
544    }
545
546    public static int hash256_alt(final long x, final long y, final long z, final long w, final long seed) {
547        long a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
548        return (int) ((0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L
549                + (a ^= 0x85157AF5L * seed + x)
550                + (a ^= 0x85157AF5L * x + y)
551                + (a ^= 0x85157AF5L * y + z)
552                + (a ^= 0x85157AF5L * z + w)
553                + (a ^= 0x85157AF5L * w + seed)) * a >>> 56);
554    }
555
556}
